messageBody:
On 2/9/07, Gabriel Nascimento <gamnascimento@...> wrote:
> My Domain Model already access objects that carry business rules
parameters.
> I simulate them using EasyMock. It´s working fine.
>
> Unit Tests are used as example of use of my API and I should call
only my
> public methods, cause that is what will be invoked by the client.
But, I
> want to test each method, and each business rule separated.
>
> So, I don´t know if changing my private validation methods to
protected,
> only for unit test using, is a bad practice...

I don't feel bad about making private methods package scope in order
to test them. Testing trumps encapsulation.

However, if I can cover (as measured with a coverage tool) the
private methods by calling public methods, I will do that rather than
test the private methods explicitly.

In most cases covering the private methods by calling the public
methods is feasible since the population of functions that call the
private methods *is* the public, protected, and package scope methods
of that class. If any line within a private method is not executed
by the unit tests of the other methods, then either you need to add a
new test case or the line in the private method is not really needed.
